ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CUSTOMS, IMMIGRATION AND QUARANTINE IN SINGAPORE

(Malaysian Government's stand and legal arguments)



    1. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether the Malaysian government has given its legal arguments for keeping its customs, immigration and quarantine (CIQ) in Singapore and, if not, whether it has indicated when this will be done.

    2. Mr Simon S C Tay asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether the Malaysian government has to date filed the grounds for its stand on the Customs, Immigration and Quarantine (CIQ) issues; and if not, what has our Government done to ensure timely progress on the resolution of the matter.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Prof. S Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take both Mr Low Thia Khiang's Question and Mr Simon Tay's Question together as they are related?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Prof. S Jayakumar: Sir, Malaysia has to date not submitted its written legal arguments.

    Members will recall that Singapore rejected Malaysia's claim that they had a legal right to operate their Customs, Immigration and Quarantine (CIQ) at Tanjong Pagar. However, we allowed them three months, until 31st October 1998, to submit

Column: 1785

written legal arguments to substantiate their claim. Five days before the 31st October deadline expired, Malaysia requested an extension of the deadline by 1 1/2 months. We agreed and accordingly extended the deadline to 15th December 1998. However, Malaysia did not submit their arguments by the 15th December deadline nor did they give us any explanation, even though our High Commissioner in Kuala Lumpur reminded them on 11th December 1998. On 16th December 1998, after the deadline had expired, Singapore sent a Third Person Note to ask the Malaysian Government for an explanation and to ask when it was submitting its legal arguments.

    Subsequently, my Permanent Secretary spoke to his counterpart in the Malaysian Foreign Ministry and informed him that we were awaiting a reply to our Third Person Note of 16th December 1998 and for their explanation why they failed to submit their arguments.

    Thereafter, the then Foreign Minister Dato' Seri Abdullah Badawi replied on 26th December 1998, referring to the meeting between the two Prime Ministers in Hanoi on 17th December 1998, where the two Prime Ministers agreed to discuss and seek solutions to all outstanding bilateral issues as a package, including the location of the CIQ. His main point was that this latest agreement between the two Prime Ministers superseded any previous undertaking or understanding at the officials level. Malaysia's understanding was therefore that the question of a deadline should no longer arise. He also mentioned that Malaysian officials would be ready to begin negotiations sometime after Hari Raya Aidilfitri.

    I replied on 30th December 1998 to point out that when the two Prime Ministers met in Hanoi on 17th December 1998, Prime Minister Goh had told Prime Minister Mahathir that Singapore's position on the CIQ issue was straightforward, namely, Malaysia would have to recognise Singapore's sovereignty and not claim that it had a legal right to operate its CIQ in Singapore. If so, he was prepared to discuss the next step. Prime Minister Goh added that although there

Column: 1786

was no legislation allowing Malaysian Immigration to operate in Singapore, he was prepared to discuss the possible location of Malaysia's CIQ facilities in Singapore as part of a package of bilateral issues to be resolved. But first of all, the question whether Malaysia still claims to have a legal right to be at Tanjong Pagar had to be resolved. Indeed, when Prime Minister Goh met the press immediately after the meeting, he told the media that Malaysia should still give Singapore their legal arguments.

    In my reply to then Foreign Minister Badawi, we have stressed that any negotiations on the location of the CIQ could proceed only after Singapore's sovereignty over Tanjong Pagar and Woodlands has been acknowledged and not disputed. This is because Malaysia has claimed a legal right for its Customs and Immigration to operate in Singapore at Tanjong Pagar. Singapore rejects this. This is a question of Singapore's sovereignty, just as Malaysian airspace is a question of Malaysia's sovereignty. When Malaysia refused RSAF permission to fly over Malaysia, Singapore acknowledged this sovereignty. We expect them to acknowledge our sovereignty.

    We have informed Malaysia that if they do not produce their legal arguments in one month's time, we will assume that they no longer wish to pursue their legal claim to be at Tanjong Pagar.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung (Bukit Timah): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether it is important to highlight the legal points in this case or should it not be subsumed under some overall negotiating position because some members of the public do raise this point? Also, may I ask whether the appointment of the new Foreign Minister, Datuk Syed Hamid Albar would have some impact on the resolution of the CIQ and other bilateral issues?

    Prof. S Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, let me take the first part of Dr Ong Chit Chung's question, ie, why we need to highlight the legal aspect. It is not so much "highlighting" the legal aspect because Members will recall that it was Malaysia which wanted the CIQ issue to

Column: 1787

be included in the package of bilateral issues to be resolved, according to the two Prime Ministers' agreement. We agreed to this. But, because Malaysia insisted that it had a legal right for its CIQ to operate in Singapore - as Members will recall the debate we had on 31st July last year - Malaysia has therefore raised a fundamental question of sovereignty.

    There really can be no two ways about it. Either Malaysia's CIQ in Singapore are there as a matter of right or they are there because of our leave and consent. If Malaysia's CIQ are in Singapore because of an inherent legal right, then of course it follows that there is no need for any negotiated political settlement because they are there as of legal right. Therefore, it is important, from Singapore's point of view, that the question of Singapore's sovereignty has to be acknowledged. We have told the Malaysians that if they do not submit their legal arguments within a month then we will assume that they no longer maintain that they have a legal right to operate their CIQ in Singapore.

    As to the Member's second question about the new Foreign Minister, let me say that I have previously worked with Datuk Seri Syed Hamid when he was Minister of Justice in Malaysia. I in fact had a very good working relationship with him in that capacity and I look forward to working closely with him to resolve outstanding bilateral issues and to strengthen bilateral relations. Members might have read in the media that the new Foreign Minister has in fact spoken quite positively on bilateral relations and has indicated a desire to work towards improving ties. According to media reports, he has said his priority would be Singapore-Malaysia ties. He said that he was optimistic and that it should not be difficult to resolve issues amicably. I welcome his remarks.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what the Government would do if Malaysia continues not to acknowledge the sovereign rights of Singapore over the CIQ issue and at the same time they also

Column: 1788

fail to submit the legal arguments but want to continue to operate their CIQ here. What would the Government do?

    Prof. S Jayakumar: I have always taken the position in this House that we should take things one step at a time. It is not that Foreign Ministries and Foreign Ministers never inquire internally on what to do if certain questions such as those posed by the Member arise. We always have to address "what if" questions. But in bilateral relations, we have to assume that things will develop one step at a time. I would not like to prejudge this issue. I would like to give the Malaysians time to respond to the position I have outlined.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): May I ask the Minister whether it is the stand of the Singapore Government that, prior to the moving of the CIQ to Woodlands, Malaysia was operating its CIQ at Tanjong Pagar simply at the will of the Singapore Government, just a bare licence, or whether there was a legal right for them to operate the CIQ at Tanjong Pagar?

    Prof. S Jayakumar: That is precisely the issue. Singapore's position is that Malaysia's operation of CIQ facilities here is not on the basis of a legal right or on the basis of extraterritorial rights. They are here on the basis of leave and consent of the Singapore Government.

    Mr Simon S C Tay (Nominated Member): The Minister mentioned a one-month further deadline, after which he presumes Malaysia would not raise the claim again. What is there to prevent Malaysia from raising the claim after this deadline? In the same connection, what is the reassurance that in packaging various issues together, Malaysia would move to the slowest common denominator?

    Prof. S Jayakumar: On the second part of the question, if they move to the slowest common denominator, then conclusion of the framework of wider cooperation, which the Prime Minister has talked about several times in this House and to which we have committed, will be that much more time-consuming. But again I would

Column: 1789

not like to assume that it will proceed on the "slowest common denominator". We have to take the position, as both the Prime Ministers explained to the press, that both want to solve the package as early as possible. They have said that they are prepared to start the discussion on the package at the officials level soon after Hari Raya Aidilfitri. We have said that we welcome that. But, first, the question of the legal issue and the question of sovereignty have to be resolved and put behind us.

    In answer to the first part of the Member's question, if that issue is not resolved, obviously we cannot proceed to the package of issues negotiations because it will not be productive. There will always be a question mark over the CIQ issue. Are we negotiating the CIQ issue on the basis of their inherent legal right? Will they claim it in future? If they claim it in future, it will mean that we have not resolved it. So it has to be resolved. It has to be put behind us. That is why this basic legal issue has to be resolved.

    Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): This being a sovereign issue, which I think is not up for negotiation, would the Minister consider referring this matter to the International Court of Justice?

    Prof. S Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, first, on a technical matter of referring the matter to the International Court of Justice, on this procedural point, it requires two countries to agree to refer a matter to the International Court of Justice. But we have not reached that stage. We will reach that stage only when we see their position. If they insist that they still have a legal right, then, as I mentioned in Parliament on 31st July last year, if they send their legal arguments, we have said that the two Attorneys-General and officials, the legal experts, will sit down and meet first and see whether it can be hammered out and resolved by a meeting of the legal experts. If they cannot resolve the issue, then we have to discuss subsequent steps and settle it by reference to judicial records in Singapore. But these are to prejudge what

Column: 1790

is going to happen. Let us first see what is the position of Malaysia.

Column: 1790

PEDRA BRANCA

(Review of outstanding issues with Malaysia)



    3. Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin asked the Prime Minister whether the proposal to review all the outstanding bilateral issues with Malaysia includes the issues of Pedra Branca.

    Prof. S Jayakumar (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I answer this question on behalf of the Prime Minister?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Prof. S Jayakumar: Pedra Branca is not among the issues which the two Prime Ministers, in their meeting in Hanoi on 17th December 1998, agreed should be settled as a package of outstanding bilateral issues. This is because, as I informed Parliament on 29th June 1998, officials from Singapore and Malaysia on 14th April 1998 had already reached the agreement on the text of a Special Agreement to refer Malaysia's claim to Pedra Branca to the International Court of Justice.

    Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin: Can I ask the Minister what is the status of the matter now being handled by the International Court of Justice?

    Prof. S Jayakumar: As I said, the text of the Special Agreement has been agreed upon. So the basic problem has been overcome. What has to happen now are procedural requirements, such as formal signing ceremony and ratification, after which it will be referred to the International Court of Justice. These procedural steps will be implemented in due course.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): May I ask the Minister whether the issue will include Malaysia's proposal to build a second bridge to replace the Causeway?

    Prof. S Jayakumar: Do I understand the Member's question to be whether the package of issues includes the proposal of a bridge?

Column: 1791



    Dr Lily Neo: Yes.

    Prof. S Jayakumar: The answer to the question is no. The proposal to replace the Causeway with a bridge is actually not part of the package of bilateral issues that Singapore and Malaysian officials have discussed. In fact, this proposal is not new, nor has it been raised officially. There were press reports, I believe, in 1996 to which Prime Minister Goh as well as my Ministry responded. But these reports resurfaced recently in a number of Malaysian press reports that a consortium called Gerbang Perdana had secured in-principle approval to construct a bridge to replace the Causeway. The Ministry of National Development issued a press statement on 18th December which reiterated that the Singapore Government had not received any official proposal from the Malaysian Government on the development of a new bridge to replace the Causeway. Only when the Singapore Government has received such a proposal and is able to evaluate it, would we be able to comment on it further?

    Sir, let me say again that any proposal to build a bridge must be agreed to by the two governments. When the Singapore Government receives a serious proposal from the Malaysian Government, we will study it and do a cost benefit analysis.

    Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin: Sir, it appears that the Singapore Government has not been consulted on matters of mutual interest and, at the same time, we have been accused of not consulting the Malaysians on other areas of mutual interest. Would the Government then consider referring this matter, as a matter of protest, to the Malaysian Government to make sure that we are equally consulted on matters of mutual interest?

    Prof. S Jayakumar: The Member's point is taken. But as I said, it is a private sector proposal. The Malaysian Government has not made a formal proposal to us. I do not think this calls for a protest. But of course we wish that Singapore is kept informed of such a proposal if the Malaysian Government does in fact support this proposal.

Column: 1792

RELEASE OF LAND SALES FOR PRIVATE PROPERTY DEVELOPMENT



    4. Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Minister for National Development if he will consider releasing land sales for private property development since property prices have stabilised in the last few months.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, as announced in June last year, Government land sales for private residential, Executive Condominium and commercial development will remain suspended in 1999, except for a site at Clark Quay MRT station. We will review the demand and supply situation again towards the end of 1999 before deciding on the land sales programme for Year 2000. There is currently no change in the Government's plan.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, as we have seen from press reports in the past few weeks, developers have increased prices of private property by as much as 17%. What this means is that the balance between demand and supply is a very delicate one. Does the Minister not feel that a one-year wait to review the prices may be too late and we may see prices escalating again at uncontrollable levels?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government would rather leave the setting of prices for properties to the market. Our job is just to ensure that there is an adequate supply to meet the demand as many market analysts have indicated, there is no lack of supply in the private property market. Today, we have more than 6,000 units which have been launched but still unsold. There are another 10,000 units not launched but with all the prerequisites for sale. So the developers are waiting for the right timing to launch these units. There are also another 10,000 units under planning without the prerequisites for sale. All in all, we have about 26,000 to 27,000 units in the pipeline. So there is no sense of urgency to release land for this year. We will again consider releasing land for next year towards the end of 1999.

Column: 1793

SINGAPORE TOURISM BOARD

(Special allowance for hotel refurbishment scheme)


    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether he will disclose the details of the Singapore Tourism Board's special allowance for hotel refurbishment scheme.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yock Suan): The Special Allowance for Hotel Refurbishment is a scheme introduced in July 1998 as part of the Government's $2 billion package of off-budget measures.

    The scheme incentivises the industry to refurbish the hotels during the current downturn, in preparation for the upturn in tourist arrivals when the regional economies recover.

    The scheme allows hotels to apply for tax allowance of up to 150% of the qualifying refurbishment expenditure. Hotels must spend a minimum of $3 million on such expenditure to be eligible for this scheme.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, what are the criteria for the assessment of the hotels which would qualify for funds under the scheme? So far, how many and which hotels have been given funds?

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: The hotels interested in refurbishing their premises should apply to the Singapore Tourism Board which will evaluate their proposals. The allowance of up to 150% is available to hotels which are within the safeguarded area. There are certain areas within the Orchard Road corridor which we have safeguarded for hotels. They are not allowed to convert to other uses. So these hotels are allowed to apply up to 150% of the Special Allowance. For other hotels, the Special Allowance could go up to 130%. They have to apply within the period. The refurbishment project must commence not earlier than 1st July last year, which was the starting date for the scheme, and finish not later than 30th June 2003. This means it is a 5-year period

Column: 1794

in which they must refurbish, and each project must not take longer than three years. The first hotel to qualify for the scheme is Marina Mandarin Hotel, as reported in the papers. There are several other applications in the pipeline.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I would like to know what are the criteria for evaluation and it seems to me that priority will be given to hotels in the safeguarded area. Besides Marina Mandarin, which has been given the funds, are there any other hotels which would be given the funds?

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: The idea of the scheme is to make use of this downturn, when tourist arrivals are lower, to upgrade the premises. I think some of the premises may be lacking, for example, IT facilities, or maybe they are a bit old. So the general idea is to be generous so long as they meet certain minimum criteria. The intention is to support them. So what I have mentioned just now is to distinguish between the safeguarded area and the areas outside. The reason is that within the safeguarded area, which is the main tourism belt, we are limiting their use of the land. In the past, when the property market was hot, they wanted to convert to condominiums. The Government said no. So for that reason, I think they deserve somewhat more favourable treatment. But otherwise, the intention is to be generous and where they meet the minimum criteria, the likelihood is that we will support them.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, my question just now was whether any other hotels were given the funds besides Marina Mandarin. The Minister says that they will be generous. How generous are they? What is the budget? Does it mean whatever amount that they have applied for? Is this scheme also applicable to small hotels?

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: The scheme is applicable to gazetted hotels, that means, they must be within a certain definition to be classifed as "hotels". I cannot remember the actual figures. It is $1

Column: 1795

million expenditure, or something like that, but I cannot remember the exact numbers. The first hotel to qualify is Marina Mandarin. But as I said, there are several other hotels in the pipeline. I do not want to mention their names because this is a private matter with them. But they are still being processed and the likelihood is that we will put up a few more for approval. This is in the nature of incentives. We want to be as generous as possible. It depends on how much they want to spend on their refurbishment.

(Statement by the Deputy Prime Minister)


    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, in his National Day Rally speech in 1997, the Prime Minister spoke of the importance of maintaining our Asian heritage, and particularly the challenge faced by the Chinese community in maintaining its roots. He highlighted two issues:

    First, reproducing a core group of Singaporeans who are steeped in the Chinese cultural heritage, history, literature and the arts. We need them to be Chinese language teachers, writers, journalists, community leaders, MPs and Ministers; and

Column: 1810



    Second, setting realistic standards for Chinese Language in schools, standards that students of average ability can achieve with a reasonable effort, especially students from English-speaking home backgrounds.

The Challenge: Achieving two objectives in parallel

    Following this, the Ministry of Education has done a comprehensive review of the teaching of Chinese language in our schools. The study involved school principals from both SAP schools and English-language schools, MOE's curriculum development staff, its policy officers, MOE's ministers, and myself. The study covered the following issues:

    (a) Encouraging more students to study Higher Chinese (HCL) in schools, and achieve a deeper understanding of Chinese culture;

    (b) Developing a few more schools with a stronger Chinese environment;

    (c) Reviewing the cultural content of the Chinese language syllabus;

    (d) Setting the appropriate standards of Chinese Language (CL) to be expected of the majority of students; and

    (e) Addressing the problems of pupils who have difficulty learning Chinese.

    The Government has accepted the study's recommendations. The policies on teaching and learning Chinese have long term implications and affect many teachers, pupils, and parents. Before I present the main changes, let me explain our overall approach to the problem.

Constant philosophy; adapting implementation

    The Government's long-standing policy on bilingualism and learning of mother tongues in schools remains unchanged. English is and will remain our common working language. It is the language of global business, commerce and technology. But the mother tongue gives us a crucial part of our values, roots and

Column: 1811

identity. It gives us direct access to our cultural heritage, and a world-view that complements the perspective of the English-speaking world. It provides us the ballast to face adversity and challenges with fortitude, and a sense of quiet confidence about our place in the world. Maintaining our distinctiveness and identity as an Asian society will help us to endure as a nation. This applies to all ethnic groups.

    In teaching the Chinese language, we have two objectives:

    (a) To develop the pupil's linguistic skills, in terms of listening, speaking, reading and writing; and

    (b) To transmit Chinese culture and traditional values through the study of CL.

    These twin objectives recognise the importance of CL as a means of transmitting culture and values. The level of language skills we can aim for will vary for different groups of pupils, depending on their aptitudes and abilities. But we want to inculcate these cultural values even in pupils who have difficulty learning CL, if necessary, partly by using English.

    While the strategic goals have remained constant, their implementation has changed over time, to adapt to changing circumstances. Most recently, in 1991 a committee chaired by then Deputy Prime Minister Mr Ong Teng Cheong reviewed the Chinese language syllabus. It recommended significant improvements to the teaching and learning of Chinese language in schools. These have since been implemented, including a completely new set of textbooks for all levels, with much improved cultural content.

Emerging trends

    However, the situation continues to develop. Several trends affect the learning and teaching of CL in Singapore:

    Firstly, the language profile of Singaporean families is changing rapidly. More Singaporean homes are now English-speaking. Younger families are

Column: 1812

much more likely to be English-speaking than older ones. In 1988, only 20% of the Primary 1 cohort came from English-speaking homes. By 1998, the figure was 40%. In 10 years, the proportion has doubled. In other words, if you look at the children in school today, the `O' level group, only 20% come from English-speaking homes, but the Primary 1 group, which has just started school, 40% come from English-speaking homes. In fact, that was last year's figures. This year, Primary 1 is 43%. The figure will continue to rise. This will have a major impact on the learning and teaching of Chinese language in our schools.

    Secondly, globalisation and the knowledge economy are putting a premium on internationally mobile talent. Successful Singaporeans have many opportunities to live and work overseas. This makes it more critical to develop among them a sense of Singaporean identity and belonging through learning the mother tongue. But it also means being more careful to make realistic demands on pupils learning CL, so that parents do not associate a Singaporean education with burdensome CL requirements.

    Thirdly, a counterbalancing factor is the continued rapid growth and opening up of China. China will be a major global player in the next century. A command of CL will be a valuable asset for many jobs and careers, even if the person does not live or work in China. This is true of the public service, and will be so in the private sector also. Singaporeans brought up to be bilingual will be at a significant advantage. This gives a practical purpose to learning CL, and will motivate pupils to master the language.

Approach to teaching Chinese

    We want every Singaporean to study his mother tongue in school for as long as possible, and to as high a level as he is capable of. The human brain has a finite capacity. Only a minority of people - at most 10-15% of the population - have the IQ and the aptitude for languages to master two languages equally well. Even fewer can think in more than one

Column: 1813

    In our schools, English is the main medium of instruction, and must be learnt at the first language level. For the mother tongue, we want pupils who can also to do it at first language level, or close to it. For the rest of the pupils, mother tongue instruction will have to be at second language level. What this second language level consists of is an empirical question, not a matter of opinion or dogma. It is what pupils of average ability can achieve with a reasonable effort. But whether a pupil learns his mother tongue at first or second language level, we will provide him the support, facilities, and incentives to make the effort.

    This approach to teaching the mother tongue, applied to Chinese, will enable us to nurture a Chinese cultural elite, especially from among those who have taken Higher Chinese and studied in SAP schools. It will also help us build a broad base of Chinese Singaporeans who have learnt CL, and will continue to use Chinese beyond the formal education system.

    The effort required of pupils to study CL must be comparable to the effort required for other subjects. It cannot be disproportionate.     The Ministry of Education is working to re-orientate the entire education system to an ability-driven paradigm. It is designing mass customisation models to allow each pupil to proceed as far as he can in the areas in which he excels. This applies to all subjects. We will adopt a more customised strategy to teaching CL in line with this overall approach. We will set different target levels of achievement for pupils of different abilities, based on what pupils of that ability level can attain given a reasonable amount of effort. This will encourage each pupil to strive for the highest standard that he is capable of.

    Some pupils are not academically outstanding all-round, but they have a strong aptitude and interest in Chinese. We should provide them with encouragement and opportunities to study HCL. Many academically outstanding pupils do HCL. But they often go on to study subjects like engineering or law, and pursue careers in business or government where they no longer use much Chinese. Fewer take up professional careers centred around Chinese language or culture, for example, in teaching, the media, or the arts. Encouraging more students whose academic results are good but perhaps not quite as outstanding to study HCL will help to build up a functional Chinese elite.

    On the other hand, there are also talented pupils who are not able to cope with existing CL standards, even though they have high cognitive ability, do well in all their other subjects, and have good potential to contribute to Singapore when they grow up. We should not turn these pupils against CL. We should encourage them to develop an interest and a basic level of mastery, which they can build on later if they need to.

    Pupils who have exceptional difficulties coping with CL are a small minority. But we cannot ignore their problems. They are overwhelmingly male (in fact, three quarters or more are males). Most but not all are from English-speaking homes.

    Not all pupils have the same home environment or natural ability in learning CL. We must recognise the large difference which the home language makes to

Column: 1815

learning CL. A CL syllabus may present no problem to a child who speaks Chinese at home. Chinese is probably his master language. His CL lessons reinforce and formalise words, phrases and grammar which, in fact, he already knows. But the same syllabus can be extremely challenging for a child who speaks English at home, uses Chinese only occasionally outside class, and for whom far from being a master language, Chinese is a totally new language which has to be learnt from scratch.

    It is also very significant that most of the pupils who are very weak in Chinese are boys. This shows that the problem of this group is not just lack of motivation, or not trying hard enough. It reflects innate differences between males and females, in brain function and aptitude for learning languages. It is a well established fact that girls are much better at languages than boys. We must acknowledge and allow for this reality. Even in this House, the ladies do very well.

    Besides customising the CL requirements to suit pupils of different abilities, in teaching CL we need to achieve an appropriate balance among the language skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing, what they call in Chinese ( ) (ting, shuo, du, xie). In adult life, most Singaporeans will more often speak and hear Chinese than read Chinese, and more often read than write Chinese. So CL teaching, and CL examinations, should emphasise more on listening and speaking skills, and also on reading skills. For Higher Chinese, the present emphasis on all four skills, including writing, should be maintained.

    To support this approach to CL, we need appropriate markers, signals and incentives. We need to encourage students through many ways to make the effort to take CL seriously and do their best. We already have schemes to recognise and reward those who excel in CL. We must build on these. We will maintain key requirements, such as requiring students to meet a certain minimum standard in CL

Column: 1816

at `O' and `A' levels to proceed on to junior college and university.

Key Proposals

    Now, let me highlight the specific changes to Higher Chinese and Chinese teaching following from the review: Encouraging More Students to Study Higher Chinese Presently, Higher Chinese is offered by 22% of upper primary school pupils and 12% of secondary school students. We will encourage more students to study Higher Chinese, as this will be the source of the future Chinese elite.

    In primary schools we will relax the criteria for allowing pupils to take Higher Chinese. They can do so provided at Primary 4 streaming they score Band 1 in Chinese Language, and at least Band 2 in English and Mathematics.

Admission to SAP Schools

    We will be more liberal in allowing pupils to take Higher Chinese, at both primary and secondary levels. In secondary schools, currently only students who score in the top 10% of PSLE, or who score within the next 10% and show their ability to handle both English and Chinese are allowed to do Higher Chinese. We will broaden this to the top 30% of PSLE students, subject to similar conditions.

    Currently, the top 10% of PSLE students are offered a second chance to opt for SAP schools after the PSLE results are published. This is called the "Second Option". We will broaden this "Second Option" to the top 30% of PSLE students who are eligible to offer Higher Chinese.

    Next, these changes should increase the proportion of pupils studying Higher Chinese, especially at secondary school. How many actually opt for Higher Chinese will depend on the pupils' choices, but we hope to raise the proportion in secondary schools from the current 12% to perhaps 15-20%.

Column: 1817



Admission to Junior College

    Currently, all students who obtain a pass in Higher Chinese are given two bonus points for JC admission. To encourage more students to take up the Chinese Language Elective Programme (LEP), we will award two additional bonus points for admission into JC to students who enrol in the LEP programme.

University

    At university, we will follow through to encourage more students to continue doing Chinese at the polytechnic and university. The number majoring in Chinese Language or Chinese Studies is unlikely to be large. But our tertiary institutions offer other courses where Chinese is useful, and ECAs related to Chinese language and culture.

    NUS has undergraduate and postgraduate programmes in Chinese Language and Chinese Studies. It runs two popular MBA programmes in Mandarin which cater to the needs of Chinese-speaking Singaporeans and foreigners. NTU offers Chinese electives to balance the mainly technological orientation of its undergraduate courses, and to broaden its undergraduate education. The polytechnics offer electives and modules on Chinese language and culture. Some polytechnic courses contain modules conducted in Chinese. There are active Chinese dance and drama groups and Chinese orchestras on university and polytechnic campuses. A small number of students visit China as exchange students on study tours.

    MOE is exploring with the universities the possibility of introducing bonus points for entry into Chinese Studies in NUS for those strong in Chinese. It is also exploring offering bonus points for those who enter Communications Studies in NTU for those strong in mother tongue, not just Chinese but any mother tongue, at the AO- and A-Level.

    The universities and polytechnics will strive to expand the range of options available, so that even those students who do not focus on Chinese language and

Column: 1818

culture can keep up their interest in Chinese and use it to valuable advantage in their careers.

Developing More Schools with a Stronger Chinese Environment

    Next, we will develop more schools with a stronger Chinese environment. We will enhance the SAP programme to improve its effectiveness and reach. Both good academic performance and a rich Chinese environment are important attributes of SAP schools. The nine schools were chosen in 1979, 20 years ago. They have helped to preserve the best of the old Chinese schools. But the list of nine schools has not been updated since, although the geographical distribution of the population has shifted, and the schools have developed at different paces.

    We have reviewed the nine SAP schools. Most are doing well, both academically and in terms of cultural enrichment. However, a few of them have rather low proportions of students qualifying to take Higher Chinese, and have fallen in their academic rankings. MOE has discussed the problem with these SAP schools, and will work with them to help them improve their standards.

    We will therefore retain all nine existing SAP schools on the programme. But in addition, we will make Nan Hua Secondary a 10th SAP school. Nan Hua will help to cater for the additional PSLE students who will now be given a Second Option to apply for a SAP secondary school, but who may not be admitted into the most popular SAP schools. Nan Hua is also in Clementi, in the Western part of the island, whereas most existing SAP schools are in the Eastern half of Singapore.

    At the Junior College level, we will set up a third centre for the Chinese Language Elective Programme (LEP), at Nanyang Junior College, as the Minister for Education announced last week. There are two existing LEP programmes which are in Hwa Chong JC and Temasek JC. However, Nanyang JC will continue to accept non-Chinese students. Indeed it has vibrant non-Chinese cultural

Column: 1819

programmes. It organises a dikir barat competition and an Indian drama festival every year, and I hope it will continue to do so.

Cultural Content of Chinese Syllabus

    As the purpose of teaching Chinese is not purely utilitarian, but to transmit heritage and values, the cultural content of the textbooks is important. While learning the language, we want the pupils to pick up stories and fables, learn about historical characters, and imbibe lessons for life.

    We have reviewed the contents of the CL and Higher Chinese textbooks. Compared to the textbooks which they replaced, the present ones are far richer and more interesting.

    However, we can improve the cultural content of the textbooks further. MOE will do so progressively as part of its curriculum review process. In addition, we will introduce an enrichment course, "Introduction to Appreciation of Chinese", for all lower secondary students in SAP schools, that means, Secondary 1 and 2.

    But we have to be mindful to maintain a balance between including more cultural material, and helping students to master the basics of the language. For example, we explored the possibility of reintroducing a few passages of classical Chinese or wen yen into the HCL textbooks. But the advice of the teachers and professionals was that the students today would have difficulty coping with them. We also cannot make the contents so dense with cultural messages and historical facts that pupils cease to relate to them. We must teach Chinese as a living language to be used in our daily lives, and not something from the past of antiquarian interest that is no longer relevant to the present.

Achievable CL Standards

    The new textbooks for CL were written after the Committee chaired by Mr Ong Teng Cheong had completed work and

Column: 1820

published their report. Since their introduction of these new textbooks in schools, MOE has received feedback from parents and teachers that the new textbooks are significantly harder than the old ones which they replaced. This had not been the intention of the Committee. Its aim had been to improve the cultural content of the textbooks, and not to raise their difficulty level. We therefore convened a panel of professional educators to review the level of the new textbooks, and specifically to compare them with old ones.

    The panel confirmed unambiguously that the new CL textbooks were significantly harder, in terms of words and phrases, grammar, content, length of passages, and overall workload on students.

    This has to be remedied. We will revise the primary and secondary CL textbooks. We will rewrite them to preserve the cultural content, but pitched at a level of difficulty that is realistically achievable by the majority of students with reasonable effort. Simplifying the language of the textbooks will make their content more accessible to students. This will lighten their load, and restore the CL standard to roughly what it was before the present textbooks were introduced.

    Rewriting the CL textbooks will take some time. Meanwhile, as an interim measure, schools will continue to use the present textbooks, but will skip certain of the more difficult passages. MOE has identified the passages to be excised, and will brief schools and parents and pupils on the details.

    As for HCL textbooks, the panel has found that the new textbooks are also more difficult than the ones they replaced. However, feedback from schools is that HCL students are generally coping with them. We will therefore not be rewriting the HCL textbooks to reduce their level of difficulty.

    This problem of textbooks having become harder raises the question whether examination standards have similarly crept up. Pupils and parents will

Column: 1821

be reassured to learn that CL examinations have not become harder. We have verified that examination standards have remained constant, especially the key PSLE and `O' level examinations, as indeed was the intention all along.

    However, we will be revising the design and format of the PSLE CL examinations, to give greater weighting to listening and speaking skills, and to test the skills that we want the children to learn. The type and nature of examination items will be revised. There should be a core of questions that most reasonably proficient students will be able to answer, and a number of more difficult questions to discriminate students who are above average and those who are outstanding from those who are average. The overall standard expected of pupils will be maintained at the present level.

    The Ministry will also review the `O' level CL examination format, but our preliminary conclusion is that the changes will be fewer than for the PSLE CL examination.

    The changes in examination and textbooks will be introduced and implemented with sufficient notice to pupils, parents and teachers to make the necessary adjustments.

Pupils Weak in CL

    The adjustment to the CL standard will mean the vast majority of pupils should be able to cope with CL. However, it will not solve the problem of the minority of pupils who find it very difficult to cope with CL even though they have no difficulty with other subjects in school. Their number is still quite small, but the proportion of English speaking families is growing. If we ignore the real problems these children have in learning Chinese, they are likely to develop a lasting aversion to the language and culture, which will be counter productive. Worse, public support for the CL policy from parents will weaken, and the Government will come under pressure to lower CL standards across the board.

Column: 1822



    To address this problem, we will introduce an alternative CL `B' syllabus, at the secondary and JC levels, for these pupils to take. This should help them to attain a basic level of proficiency in CL, and hopefully instil in them a positive interest in Chinese culture, traditions and values. At the same time, it will enable us to maintain a higher standard for the majority of pupils who have no difficulty coping with the Higher Chinese and CL syllabi.

    The CL `B' syllabus will be similar in teaching and content to CL, but with simpler texts and a smaller word list. The examination format will give greater weightage to listening to and speaking Chinese, as these are skills that are likely to be of most use to this group of pupils later on in life. A pass in CL `B' syllabus at the `O' and `A' level examinations will qualify students to enter JC and university. However, the CL `B' syllabus result cannot be used to compute the `O' level aggregate for admission into JC, or earn any `A' level points used for university admission.

    We decided against introducing CL `B' syllabus at the primary level. We want to encourage all Chinese pupils to strive to do well in CL and not give up easily, as our policy objective is to have all Chinese Singaporeans learn CL for as long as possible and to as high a level as possible. Currently, weak pupils are putting in extra effort at the PSLE, and the results show that the vast majority are coping. MOE will monitor the situation in primary schools and re-consider this if a problem develops later.

    CL `B' syllabus is not intended as a soft option in lieu of CL. MOE will work out safeguards and incentives to ensure that students who are able to cope with CL will continue to offer CL, and not opt for CL `B' syllabus. MOE estimates that 80-90% of each cohort should be capable of doing Higher Chinese or CL, so only a minority will need to do CL `B' syllabus.

    MOE will work out the implementation details for this new syllabus. CL `B' can be made available to pupils sitting for their GCE `O' and `A' level examinations in 2001, at the earliest.

Column: 1823



Other Mother Tongues

    Although our review has focused on Chinese Language, the philosophy and approach behind the CL policy framework also applies, with suitable modifications, to the teaching and learning of other mother tongue languages.

    MOE has started to review the Tamil Language syllabus to ensure that the standard is appropriate and not too difficult. We will introduce `B' syllabus for Tamil and Malay, if this proves necessary.

Conclusion

    The policies I have outlined are a refinement and updating of the existing framework, not a dramatic change. They will guide the teaching and learning of Chinese Language in schools. They will provide pupils and parents, teachers and curriculum specialists a clear understanding of the principles and rationale behind the Government's policies on Chinese Language.

    These changes will help to maintain a Chinese cultural elite as one important component to our multi-racial society. They will also give all Chinese Singaporeans enough mastery of CL to acquire the cultural values and heritage that are part of our social DNA.

    The shift in language patterns among Singaporeans reflects the broader changes in Singapore society. We have undergone a momentous transformation in one generation and the transformation is far from over. Singapore society must continue to adapt, to stay abreast and relevant to the global economy.

    We will need to review our mother tongue policies regularly, to take into account the continuing evolution of our society, changes in the external environment, as well as new research into language learning. A flexible and realistic approach to teaching and learning mother tongues will keep them alive and flourishing in Singapore and help us to maintain our Asian heritage and identity in a rapidly changing world.

pore has pursued the bilingual policy for more than 30 years. How many bilingual talents have we nurtured? The population census in the year 2000 will be able to give us the statistical figures with regard to bilingual Singaporeans.

    I suggest that in the Education Ministry's survey on the students' background, other than "English", "Mother Tongue" and "Dialect", an additional category of "Bilingual" be placed under "Language Used at Home". I believe that there are many families nowadays who use two languages at home.

    For the survival and development of our country and society, the bilingual policy should stay. This direction must not change. However, at present there are two trends that affect the implementation of the bilingual policy. The first trend is the rise of China. As China's international stature grows with each passing day, and as it becomes an economic power, the practical value of spoken and written Chinese is greatly enhanced, and the status of Chinese culture is also raised. The result of this is that more parents are willing to let their children learn Chinese, even Higher Chinese.

    At present, the vast majority of parents agree that by learning Chinese, their children can at the same time absorb Chinese culture and traditional values. Moreover, Chinese also has practical value in economics, the media and Cyberspace. Whatever the motives or intentions for learning Chinese may be, this external trend will have a positive effect on the learning and the usage of Chinese.

    Yet another trend is the change in the linguistic profile in Singapore homes. In 1988, 15 per cent of the Chinese students came from English-speaking families. In 1998, this number has increased to 33 per cent. If we consider only the Primary One students, the percentage of students who are of English-speaking family background increased from 20 per cent to 40 per cent over the past ten years. This figure will continue to grow with each passing year.

Column: 1827



    Some of these Chinese students from English-speaking families face great difficulties when they learn Chinese because they lack the support of a Chinese-speaking background at home. This trend has negative effects on the learning of Chinese in Singapore.

Different students have different abilities

    In the short run, we cannot determine the net result of the convergence of these two different trends. But the undeniable reality is: different students will have different abilities, interests and motives in learning the different subjects. The aptitude for mathematics and science is often quite different from the aptitude for learning languages. Moreover, the language spoken at home and the environment at school also affect the students' interest and ability in learning a language. Therefore, it is impractical to demand that all students attain similar results in all their various subjects.

    Thus, the focus of Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's proposed framework for Chinese education is on having a more flexible approach in teaching Chinese. This puts into effect Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong's proposal for a Chinese elite, suggested in his 1997 National Day Rally. This also solves the problem of the difficulties faced by some students from English-speaking homes in learning Chinese, referred to in PM's speech.

    The Ministry of Education will allow and encourage more Chinese students to opt for Higher Chinese. It is setting up another Special Assistance Plan (SAP) school, and starting the third Language Elective Programme (LEP) at Nanyang Junior College. It is also giving these students more incentives and rewards as they enter junior colleges and even tertiary educational institutions. For those students who are interested in and have the aptitude for Chinese, this package will provide them with more opportunities to improve the standards of their Chinese. This package

Column: 1828

should be welcomed by the Chinese-speaking community. It also satisfies the need for nurturing a Chinese elite for the next generation.

Fewer candidates for Chinese Literature

    The Ministry of Education should also encourage those students with the interest and the ability to take up Chinese Literature besides Higher Chinese. During the opening ceremony for the 1997 Speak Mandarin Campaign, DPM Lee mentioned that out of 28,000 Chinese students taking the `O' Levels, only 2,500 took the Higher Chinese paper. The number of candidates for Chinese Literature was even more dismal - a mere 500. However, the number of English Literature candidates was 11,000. The Chinese elite ought to have some knowledge of Chinese Literature.

    On the other hand, we cannot ignore those students who have special problems in learning Chinese. In the announced framework for teaching CL, they will be allowed to opt for the Chinese "B" Syllabus paper (CLB), so as to reduce the pressure they face when they learn Chinese. I believe that this policy will be welcomed by the parents of these students.

    However, the worry of the Chinese-speaking community is this: if the choice were to be entirely left to the parents, the number of students who opt for CLB would increase in tandem with the increasing number of English-speaking households in the years to come. Will CLB become a "soft-option" subject? Whether these students should become part of a "soft-option" syndrome? There are causes for worry.

    Therefore, the Ministry of Education should lay down a clear set of rules to prevent such an occurrence. For instance, the school will have to assess and decide whether the student who does well for all other subjects except Chinese is unable and not unwilling (    ) to improve his or her Chinese grades. Only then can he or she opt for CLB. Students opting for CLB must also consider that they will have to continue taking it in

Column: 1829

junior colleges. Their schools will not allow them to switch to taking Chinese as a Second Language (CL2) as and when they like it. In a nutshell, the framework for teaching CL not only encourages students to take up Higher Chinese and CL2, it must also set certain restrictions on students taking the CLB option.

    Under present circumstances, I believe most Chinese students will still choose CL2. When the Education Ministry revised the CL2 syllabus, its guiding principle was to simplify the language to make it easier to learn, without changing the cultural content. On the whole, this can be achieved.

Zaobao's language more accessible

    There was a precedent. Years ago, the Ministry of Culture requested that the Chinese newspapers simplify their language. After years of effort, Lianhe Zaobao's language has become more accessible and readable, and its contents varied and informative. It is also one of the more authoritative newspapers in the region.

    I believe that the setting of the syllabus must be guided by two important principles. The first is to transmit culture and the right values. The other is to make the lessons interesting. We need not be too insistent in other areas. In 1997, I went through eight Higher Chinese textbooks (a total of 160 lessons) in two days. I really have to take my hat off to the people who compile these textbooks.

    Not only do these lessons have to transmit cultural content and values, the lessons themselves aim to be as diversified as possible in literary form. Besides poetry, novels and essays, they also include formatted writing such as notices and letters. In terms of subject matter, these lessons also aim to divesify to meet different needs, and they include issues ranging from ASEAN economic cooperation and Southeast Asia non-nuclear proliferation zone, to environmentalism and trade protectionism. But this is a thankless task. The end result is that some of the lessons are boring and are not likely to stir the student's interest.

    In the compilation of Chinese lessons, there is actually a wide range to choose from . Besides Chinese idioms and popular poems, excerpts from vernacular novels of the Ming and Qing Dynasties, Jin Yong's kungfu novels, the translations of "Aesop's Fables" and Edmondo De Amicis' "Cuore" can be included, as well as works by Yu Qiuyu, Cai Zhizhong, Li Lien Fung, You Jin, Ng Wai Choy and so on. The question is deciding which ones to use and how to get the students interested. Most of the lessons must also include cultural content and transmit values.

    The hope of the Chinese-speaking community is that all Chinese students can achieve the highest achievable standards in CL. All the Education Ministry can do is to encourage the majority of the Chinese students to try their best to achieve the highest standards they can possibly achieve. But the ministry can also encourage the more able students to aim for higher standards, while at the same time enabling the less able students to grasp the most basic Chinese.

    Using such a flexible method to teach Chinese will not only make learning Chinese in schools more effective and interesting, more importantly, it can make them use Chinese even after they leave their schools and make Chinese a living language.

The conditions for switching to CL `B' should be restrictive and not too relaxed, so that there will not be too many students attracted to it. If you go to China to do business, you may need to use Chinese. But they are only the minority. Such a reasoning is not entirely groundless. As a matter of fact, in Singapore, using English alone, you can still carry on with your career development. However, the choices before us are:

    (1) Continue to implement our bilingual policy; or

    (2) Let it be gradually transformed into a monolingual policy.

    If we are to develop into a monolingual society where everyone speaks only English, then our whole spiritual outlook and characteristics will be changed. It will be more difficult for us to maintain our cultural traditions and to inculcate traditional values. Our linkage with the ethnic Chinese people all over the world will be weakened. It will be a great loss to our personal development and collectively it will not be good for the long term benefit of Singapore.

    In the Chinese community there may be some people who are still worried that this policy adjustment may result in a lowering of the standard of the Chinese language. This is surely not the intent and purpose of the new measures. DPM Lee has just announced that the Government will be encouraging more students to take Higher Chinese, and the Chinese Language Elective Programme (LEP) will be introduced at the Nanyang Junior College. These new measures will be

    Sir, in reviewing the teaching of our second language and our language policy, in particular, we should ask ourselves the basic question of what we want our society to be in the next millennium. I think we have to accept the fact that we can never replicate, in the case of the teaching of Chinese as a second language, the full extent of Chinese civilisation and culture in Singapore for posterity, and should we?

We have to build a multi-racial nation that is uniquely and distinctly Singapore. While we may each retain our distinct ethnic grouping, there is an overarching need to subordinate this to the higher need of forging common bonds among the different races, which transcend ethnic ties. Our language policy must therefore serve that purpose.

I went to an English school and learnt Chinese as a second language, although I cannot say I am very good at it. Yet, as a fourth generation Chinese in Singapore, I cannot say that I am as much a Chinese as my fellow Chinese in China, Taiwan or Hong Kong are. I am not sure whether I want to be. I wonder sometimes whether practices like the mid-Autumn festival, wherein we tell our children that in China this is a time when the harvest is gathered, will continue to have the same significance for us three generations or four generations down the road.

Column: 1854

be distilled from the language and be imparted to our children. Through the teaching of the second language in our schools, these values are reinforced and in the process help to promote our nation building efforts. Therefore, not just the case of the teaching of the Chinese language alone, the teaching of the other mother tongues such as Malay and Tamil in our schools should work towards the goal of building and reinforcing our common national values.

We should accept the basic proposition that our second language should seek to reinforce our nation building efforts and incidental to that, to preserve our cultural heritage while recognising that our heritage will continue to evolve in a way that makes it uniquely Singaporean. For this reason, the changes to our policy on the teaching of Chinese as a second language is welcome and I support it.

    The human brain is not unlike the computer, which the Chinese described as dian nao (electronic brain). When I was first asked to use the Chinese word-processing software, my computer was a 386, which was basically meant for software in the English language only. At that time the Chinese software was just still in its infancy stage of development. Because the nature of our work in the Chinese newspaper office required us to

Column: 1869

use Chinese word-processing technology, we were told to install the Chinese software into our English-environment computers. Disaster struck. The 386 did not have enough memory and capability to support the additional Chinese software. The computer "hanged" all the time.

    The same goes with the human brain. Just like the `electronic brain', the absorption power, retention power and the power to accommodate data and operations differ from person to person. Some people are born 286s or 386s. But some are born 486s, and the exception ones may be born Pentiums. Some of us may be able to say, "I am proficient in one language and have some working knowledge of another language. But nobody can truthfully swear that he or she is perfectly bilingual. No one dares to lay claim to that. This is because we are constrained by our endowed capability, our learning capacity.

    The maximum capacity of the hardware of a computer is finite and fixed, while its software may have certain operational capacity. These two factors together constrain its application. The same applies to the human brain. If you want to insist on one model of language policy for all students and fix a uniform standard for all, it will not work. After implementing our bilingual policy for some three decades, we have learnt to be flexible and sensitive to the different capacities of the students. This is to reduce the attrition rate in our education system because if the policy is too rigid, certain people will be sacrificed. With this new policy, I believe we will be able to encourage all students to learn their mother tongue according to their aptitude and ability. This is the advantage of this new policy.

    A good policy is one that is realistic and capable of adapting to the different situations. At the same time, I would like to point out that the Government must adopt a more positive approach to ensure that our society will not suffer in the long run. In other words, our bilingual policy will be able to continue unshaken for a long time to come. From the policy statement of DPM Lee, it is noted that the Government

Column: 1870

has already paid attention to the fact that a small group of students have difficulty in learning Chinese.

    On the other hand, it is noteworthy that more and more Chinese families are switching to English as the language spoken at home, unlike in the past when dialects or Mandarin was predominant. In other words, for children born into such families, their mother tongue is English and not Mandarin or any of the Chinese dialects. The emergence of such a situation has a very serious effect on our language policy. It is a great challenge to us. It will possibly give rise to the following situations:

    (1) Parents of English-speaking families, because of their prejudice against the Chinese language, will resist it.

    (2) Parents themselves realise the importance of their children learning Chinese. Subjectively, they hope that their children will learn and master the Chinese language. But the students themselves encounter difficulties in the process of learning Chinese in school. There is a sort of psychological pressure on the parents. The parents will then turn the pressure on the Government to lighten their children's burden on the study of Chinese language.

    I am worried about the second situation because children from the purely English-speaking families tend to find learning Chinese more difficult because they have to start from zero, unlike those who come from Chinese-speaking families who must certainly enjoy a head-start. In these circumstances, does it mean that the bilingual education policy will one day face such great pressure from the anxious English-speaking parents that the Government will be forced to lower the standard of Chinese in school. Even at this present moment when we are having an established bilingual education policy in place, we are finding the grounds more and more difficult to defend. In future, we may even succumb to pressure and go into a monolingual society. I believe we do not like to see such a situation arising.

    Now we are introducing CL `B' for students who have difficulty in learning Chinese. According to the present

Column: 1871

estimate, the number of such students is not significant. But, with the transformation of the language background of the younger families, the number of such students is bound to increase in future, that is to say, there may be more and more students opting for CL `B' in future. If this happens, we can foresee that by that time, these students and their parents will be putting pressure on the Ministry of Education to recognise the result of CL `B' at `O' level examination for admission to the junior college, and at `A' level examination for university matriculation. I certainly do not wish to see this situation arising. However, we must be psychologically prepared for such a situation to arise in the future. In the interest of our nation, apart from taking preventive measures, we must also take positive and proactive measures to strengthen the overall environment for the development of bilingualism in our society. In other word, we must continue to insist on making Mandarin work in our society.

    Some people say we have been very successful in our Speak Mandarin campaign. I do not think so. I think the future challenge is even greater, especially in the Chinese community. The promotion of Mandarin-speaking is still a very big task to accomplish. The Chinese community should recognise the transformation of language background of the ethnic Chinese families in Singapore. The Chinese community should put in more efforts to promote the use of Mandarin in our society. Chinese should not be treated merely as a subject to be learnt in school. It should be promoted as a useful tool of communication in our society. It is only then that we will be able to effectively preserve our bilingual education policy. It is in the long-term interest of our country that the bilingual education policy be maintained.

    Sir, I support the policy statement.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)(In Mandarin): Sir, I have three regrets. The first regret is that we have to debate such an important issue in Parliament without due notice in advance. There are so much

Column: 1872

    Secondly, I heard Mr Kenneth Chen talking about his son who was denied a place in our local university because he could not pass his CL2, and had to send him overseas to get his degree. This is my second regret.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the language policy is a very important policy of the nation. It is not just a superficial policy that involves just the application of a language in our education system. It actually involves our people's ability of expression, their upbringing, and the differences in our values. What is the direction in which our language policy is heading? Shall we use Chinese as a mainstream language or English as a mainstream language, or any other language as a mainstream language? Of course, the value will become the mainstream value of our society. So the direction we take will eventually decide what type of society we will develop into. So I feel that the language policy is not just an education policy. It is a national policy of great importance.

    In Singapore, we have been implementing the so-called bilingual education system for the past few decades. The question is: what is the definition of a bilingual system? In the old days, students

Column: 1873

in the Chinese schools used Chinese as a first language and English as a second language. For those in the English language schools, English was the first language and Chinese was promoted as one of the second languages or not promoted at all. Now we do not have the so-called "Chinese stream" or "English stream". The first language is English and apart from those taking Higher Chinese, mother tongue is basically a second language. So, is our so-called bilingual education a misnomer? It gives people the misconception that we are bilingual. But, in fact, the levels of our languages are vastly lopsided. So we should not call it a bilingual system. It should be more appropriately known as a mother tongue system where Malay, Tamil or Chinese is a second language. Actually, what we should be concerned with is the effect of the introduction of CL `B' on the future development of our society.

    I am more worried about the ability of expression of our people. For English-speaking people, they may not be able to speak Chinese because their standard of Chinese is no good. But most of the time, they will be able to absorb the essence of the English language. They will be able to express themselves fairly well in English. But, on the other hand, for those who come from Chinese-speaking families, they cannot speak English well, and because of the second language system in our school, their standard of Chinese is also not good enough for them to express themselves well. So it results in neither here nor there. In the end, their Chinese is no good and their English is also no good. From the younger generation that I know, I have already noticed that this problem is very serious. In their conversation, they mix Chinese with English. They are unable to speak and express eloquently in one language. This is something that we should be worried about.

    With regard to the standard of Chinese language, first of all, the Government has to decide what is the bottomline for its desired level of the Chinese language. Is the bottomline such that Chinese, being one of the official languages in Singapore, will continue to be used in Singapore or

Column: 1874

do you want to promote Chinese as a gateway to understanding Chinese culture or to use it as a means to train the so-called Chinese elite? I think the different purposes will decide what will be the appropriate standard of Chinese language we want to have. If Chinese is just to be regarded as an official language so that it could continue to be used in Singapore, then very simply, a lower standard would suffice to serve the Government's policy. As long as you can speak and understand it, that is enough.

    But if you want to use Chinese as a means to enhance our understanding of the Chinese culture, what standard do you need? If you want to cultivate a Chinese elite, what would be the appropriate standard we must achieve? If we want to train a Chinese elite, do we not want to have more ethnic Chinese students attaining a certain level of proficiency in their Chinese, or just a handful of elite who can attain a higher level of Chinese language proficiency? I think the Government should look into it, because different people may have different needs. If you say you require our students to learn only up to primary school level or, say, 1,000 words, then so be it. But let everybody be very clear about it. Let us know what is the bottomline, what is the requirement. On the other hand, for those who are very keen to learn the Chinese language, let them know the limits that can be offered in our schools, so that they will not have false hope. The Chinese language teachers will also have a good idea of the standard they must achieve.

    Another problem is, like what Mr Goh Choon Kang has said just now, the proposed CL `B'. There would be some inherent problems that come with the introduction of CL `B'. Would this be a new standard of requirement of the Government? Would this bottomline be further lowered because of pressure from certain quarters? If we look at the background of the students, they have this problem because they come from an English-speaking family. This is something that is inevitable, but it is a vicious cycle. Now, just because these students come from such a background, we provide a lower level CL `B' to suit them. Eventually, it

Column: 1875

would come a time when there are more and more students opting to go into CL `B'. Later on in life, when these students get married, have children of their own, the language of communication will again be English, and more and more families will be speaking English. So this becomes a vicious cycle.

    According to the survey report, when the students grow older, their interest in learning Chinese becomes more and more minimal. In Primary 2, 51.3% of students say they like Chinese very much. But when it comes to junior college, only 5% of students are very interested in Chinese. Why is there such a situation? I think we should look into this matter from liking, very fond of the language, until a point where they do not like the language, or even hate the language. We should find out what is the reason for this. If we want to cultivate a so-called Chinese elite or to enhance the standard of Chinese, it is not only just to speak Chinese but to attain such a standard where you will be able to read, understand and analyse some articles in Chinese. Teaching Chinese as a subsidiary subject in school is just not enough.

    The Government should consider having some other examination subjects, eg, history or literature, being taught in Chinese, and examined in Chinese. Through the learning of these subjects in Chinese, those students who are interested in Chinese would be able to attain a certain standard in the language that will enable them to read Chinese as a major subject in the university.

    Generally speaking, the crux of the matter is, basically, people who have very little contact with Chinese will have great difficulty learning it. I must admit that Chinese is not an easy language to learn because it is a very different system from English and the other western languages. The Chinese word, or character, is an ideograph, unlike romanised spelling like in English. Chinese is more difficult to learn, but then we should not emphasise on the economic value of Chinese all the time. I think we should ask ourselves this

Column: 1876

question: As an ethnic Chinese, should I not know Chinese? This is a basic question. It is not a question of whether it has any economic value or not. The correct attitude should be: I need to, at least, have a basic understanding, a basic level of competence, in handling the language. I think the question of level, how to adjust, to fine-tune and to adapt to the needs of the students from the different backgrounds, is secondary. Most importantly, we must cultivate the correct attitude.

    There are a few things that we have to pay attention to. First, the Government's stand on Chinese. What is the Government's stand? What is the Government's expectation of Chinese in Singapore? What is the basic requirement? Will this bottomline be changing all the time, and eventually it will come to a point where you may or may not have Chinese at all. So I think the Government should take a very clear stand on its required standard that is expected of the Chinese students in Singapore.

    Secondly, the Chinese language teachers are also a very important factor. Traditionally, Chinese teachers are more serious in nature. But it is common knowledge that when a student does not like the teacher, he or she will also hate the subject he teaches. So if you want the students to enjoy learning Chinese, the Chinese language teachers should also try to be more relaxed in their teaching. They should not be so stern all the time. They should introduce more lively materials. I think the Chinese language teachers should seriously look into this matter.

    Thirdly, for the people who work in the Chinese educational, cultural and journalistic fields, we should try to tell the stories from ancient China in a more lively mood, so that they can be accepted by the younger generation. We all know that the animated movie Mulan, which is a Walt Disney production in the USA, was taken from a traditional Chinese story. But it was translated and produced as a full-length Walt Disney animated movie. Students from Chinese-speaking background or English-speaking environment alike fall for the repackaged story. It is the new packaging that makes the difference!

    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh: Thank you, Mr Speaker, for giving me these few moments. I just want to seek a few points of clarification and make some suggestions.

vision for Singapore is really a multi-cultural and multi-lingual Singapore characterised by all these specialists, who standing on their own cultural heritage, are able to appraise the world and the other cultures around them and help to nourish a Singapore identity that can be shared.
