    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): Mr Speaker, allow me to address some of the issues that have been raised by Members today before the Deputy Prime Minister rounds up the debate.

    First of all, what is our language policy and what is the standard we strive for in Chinese? Sir, we live in a multi-racial society. Bilingualism is the cornerstone of our education system. Our policy is for English as the first language and the main language of instruction in our schools. This policy has served us well. It has given us access to technology in the world. It has served us well in business and in foreign relations. It has also been a unifying factor among all the races in Singapore.

    Our policy for the mother tongue, Chinese as well as Malay and Tamil, and the other non-Tamil Indian languages, is

Column: 1887

for every child to learn his mother tongue for as long as possible and to as high a level as possible. There is therefore no one standard that we can apply to the learning of the mother tongue. We are not a homogenous society, like Germany or Japan. We are a multi-racial society. Perhaps, if our society were homogenous and we were several degrees of latitude further north and several degrees of longitude further east, we might be able to achieve the aspirations that Mr Low Thia Khiang talks about of having Chinese as the language in Singapore. Instead, we need to set standards that are appropriate. Therefore, we have the standard bearer (we are talking about the Chinese language now) and the standard bearer is Higher Chinese, then a level which is suitable for the vast majority of Chinese Singaporeans, which is CL, and for those who despite putting in a considerable effort are unable to make it, CL `B'. This set of principles will also apply to the other mother tongue languages in Singapore.

    Let me now address the specific issues that have been raised within this context and this structure of the language policy in Singapore. First, CL `B'. Dr Ow Chin Hock, Dr Ker Sin Tze, Mr Peh Chin Hua and others have asked whether or not CL `B' will become a soft option. There is a remarkably strong desire among Chinese Singaporeans today to study Chinese. For example, at the PSLE, at the streaming at Primary 4, something like 13-14% of students qualify to do Higher Chinese in the EM1 stream, but in fact many parents opt for their children to study Higher Chinese, so that something like 22-23% opt to do Higher Chinese. This is one illustration of the strength of the desire for students in Singapore and for parents in Singapore to want their children to study Higher Chinese.

    The only incentive that they have for this is really a couple of bonus points if they do decide to go to one of the nine, now 10, SAP schools. Otherwise, studying Higher Chinese in primary school gives them no other benefit beyond taking standard CL in primary school. So even

Column: 1888

relatively small incentives do encourage parents to want to have their children do Higher Chinese and also there is a strong desire, other than incentive reasons, that parents want their children to do Higher Chinese. In fact, it would seem to me that the desire is so strong that even Mr Chiam is trying to crack his jaws to learn Chinese at his age. It shows that the Speak Mandarin campaign does work, Mr Chiam, if you too are struggling to learn Chinese. When we implement CL `B', we will still continue to encourage students to go as far as they can in Chinese. We have put in a number of incentives for students to study Higher Chinese. Similarly, there will be incentives for students to study CL as opposed to CL `B'. Let me give Members a few examples.

    What we would do is to implement CL `B' from Secondary 3 upwards, which means that students from Primary 1 to Secondary 2 will study CL or HCL, and only if they are unable to cope, the teachers will of course be involved with this assessment, will they be given the option of taking CL `B'. CL `B' will also only meet the qualification requirements for JC and university, which means that students give up something quite considerable when they take CL `B'. This means that for JCs, they are unable to count their CL scores for admission to JC, and for university they do not get any point in the calculation of those 76 points for admission to university. So when a student takes up CL `B' at Secondary 3, he knows that there are implications along the way. The benefit for him is that he will be able to do the language at the level which he can probably cope with and would get a pass that would qualify him to JC or university, but he will not get points which will give him an advantage over other students. So these are already fairly strong incentives, and disincentives, if you like, for taking CL as opposed to CL `B'.

    Prof. Chin has asked what schools would offer CL `B'. Our intention is that CL `B' would be available in all schools where there is a demand for it. Of course, the SAP schools will not be offering CL `B', as that would be running quite counter to what the SAP schools are there for.

    Mdm Chiang talks about stigmatisation and whether or not we would be creating even more groups of students by introducing a CL `B'. I would urge Mdm Chiang and all parents not to treat streaming and grouping of students in this rather, I would say, old-fashioned way. What we are trying to build in our education system is an ability-driven system where we will try and customise the courses and the programmes that the students take, according to their ability in those particular subjects. I would rather move away from this idea of stigmatisation and to look at it from the point of view of providing opportunities for students to play to their strength and still learn a basic level of other subjects where they are not as strong.

    Let me move now to the opposite set of issues from CL `B', which is whether or not we can re-create Chinese schools of the past. I am surprised that Mr Chiam is advocating such a policy. As I said, the bilingual policy has been in place for many years in Singapore and has served us well. I do not see us going back on that. In fact, when given a choice today, parents opt to put their children in English stream and to study as much English as possible. In fact, that is one of the major concerns of parents. We do have a stream called ME3, which is the complement of the EM3 stream in primary school. I am not surprised that most Members have not heard of this, but it has been in existence since 1991. In the ME3 stream, students can offer mother tongue at first language level and basic English at a lower level. But since it was introduced in 1991, no one has opted for this stream.

    So what we can do and what we will do is to create a strong environment for learning Chinese, for promoting Chinese culture and values in our 10 SAP schools. We will continue to strengthen these schools. We have also opened up the Language Elective Programme in another junior college, Nanyang Junior College, and I am quite optimistic that this junior college will be able to generate the functional specialists, if you prefer, that we would desire in our society. In fact, quite at random, I asked two students whom I met when I visited the Nanyang Junior

Column: 1890

College what they would like to do after they have finished. Both of them told me: to teach. I was very heartened by this. Three of the nine journalists who were there on that day for the press conference came from Nanyang Junior College. I was quite heartened.

    Another set of issues was with regard to whether or not we could take other subjects in Chinese as this would provide a broader range of experiences and a broader range in which the language is used beyond just studying it as a language. Mr Peh Chin Hua, Dr Ow Chin Hock and others raised this. Chinese Literature is already available in our schools. We are going to make an Introduction to Appreciation of Chinese as an enrichment course in the SAP schools for all the lower secondary students. We hope that with this more of the students in the SAP schools will be encouraged to take Chinese Literature. We also have, at the junior college level, General Studies in Chinese. This is like GP, but in Chinese. Those students who have a particular love for Chinese and a facility with the language do take General Studies in Chinese. We hope that with the encouragement of a broader band of students taking CL in secondary schools and at junior college more students will be motivated to take up these subjects as well.

    The third type of issue that I would like to raise is on teacher and teaching methodology. Mr Loh Meng See, Mr Kenneth Chen, Prof. Chin and Mdm Claire Chiang, among others, raised this issue. I particularly welcome Mr Ang Mong Seng's encouragement to our CL teachers. They work very hard. They have a difficult job to do and they try very hard to do it well. I have spoken to the Teachers' Unions and I have spoken to many of the teachers, and they are putting in a lot of effort to improve the teaching methodologies in the school. The Ministry is doing its best to recruit good Chinese teachers and for that matter, good mother tongue teachers in all the mother tongue languages. Again, we hope that with this regeneration of specialists in Chinese we will be able to have a bigger pool to draw upon in order to recruit our Chinese language teachers. In fact, when I visit the

Column: 1891

schools, I see both young and enthusiastic Chinese teachers, and I see also old and enthusiastic Chinese teachers. It is the approach that they take and not their age, which is a major factor. And in this area, both the Ministry and the Teachers' Unions have been quite proactive in getting the teachers to be trained and re-trained, in teaching methodologies, as well as in teaching technologies, for example, in the use of information technology and computers.

    The Ministry of Education, as you know, is putting in computers and information technology in schools in a major way, and we are also developing a lot of software for use in the mother tongue languages. This, I hope, will help to make the teaching and the learning of mother tongue more interesting. I am not sure if all the CD-ROMs will turn out like Mulan, but I hope that the interactive nature and the fact that students can learn on their own, at their own pace, do revision, and look at the things again and again if they want to, will help them to learn better and to improve their standards.

    As I said again, Sir, the basic principle upon which the language policy in our schools is founded is quite clear. There is no doubt that we have bilingualism - English as the main language, mother tongue to as high a level as possible. We live in a multi-racial society. These are the facts that we have in Singapore and these are the factors upon which we have to try to build both a modern society open to the world, as well as a society that is well-rooted in its traditions and its values.

I would like to know from him what is the basic standard of Chinese that will be attainable, let us say, under the new scheme of CL `B'.

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have just explained that we have to customise education in Singapore to students of different ability levels. So Higher

Column: 1892

Chinese is a standard bearer, CL is a level which the vast majority of students can reach, and CL `B' will be a basic level which students who face difficulties and have put in a lot of effort should be able to reach. We expect that the CL `B' standard will be somewhere about the Secondary (Normal) standard for Chinese, but with a heavier emphasis on aural and oral skills.

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, Admiral Teo has addressed most of the points raised by the Members. I would like to sum up in Mandarin. But before I do that, I just want to take up one important point which Admiral Teo did not cover, and this was the remark by Dr Tan Cheng Bock that we should not talk about Chinese elite, and this was picked up by Mdm Claire Chiang.

    We can change the word, if you find another word more convenient. But I think the argument is not about vocabulary but about a very important concept, which is this - Singapore society is not homogenous. It is multi-racial; it is multi-religious; it is multi-cultural. And indeed even within the Chinese society, there is quite a clear differentiation between the Chinese language group and the English-speaking group. This diversity, this variation, is in fact one of the sources of our strength. It is like a rope with many fibres in it, wound together, and therefore deriving strength from one another. If we were homogenous as one Chinese-speaking society amongst the Chinese, I think we will be weaker as a country, because I think the link between the Chinese community and the minority communities will he harder to establish without English as a common ground. If we were completely English-speaking amongst the Chinese community, or minimally Chinese literate and mainly English-speaking, I think we would also be weaker, because we would not have that cultural anchor, that root, that strength, which hold us in time of difficulty. The people who come out from the different streams come out in different moulds. They are different. You look at him, you watch him walk a few metres, and you say, "This one is a Hwa Chong child or Hwa Chong alumnus." Or that is RI, and that one looks very much like ACS - Mr

Column: 1893

Chiam. You can tell, they are different. ACS is a very good school; RI is an even better school. Probably so, but if all of Singapore were ACSians and Rafflesians, I think we would be the poorer for it, because we would be without the Chinese schools, we would be without the people with the Islamic culture, we would be without the Hindu culture. And you would lose that ballast and that sense of continuity and Asian roots, which are important to our survival as a nation.

    I do not think in the future that Chinese component of our society will be exactly the same as it was in the past. Because the historical past is different, the circumstances are different, the situation which made the Chinese elite and establishment what it was before and after the world and in the 1960s has changed. We are in the 1990s, about to go into the 21st century. So the challenges are different. But to want to maintain that, so that you not only have individuals who are very proficient in Chinese and can make speeches; not only teachers, journalists and Ministers but also a certain sub-segment of our society with a certain cohesion of itself, and with the individuals to be at the top of that segment to be teachers, to be principals, to be in the clans, to be in the Chambers of Commerce, to be in the literary arena to write, to paint, to put on drama; I think that is something extra and different. If you do not like the word "elite", you think it is elitist, change it to something else - Top of the Pyramid, those who are natural leaders of the community, if you will - but that is what we want to preserve and it goes beyond Chinese language, and it is a very important motivation for what we do.

    So, let me summarise in Mandarin, because I think the points which MPs have raised have already mainly been met and also because the MPs have been supportive and understanding of the purpose of this exercise.

    (In Mandarin) Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the Members who have spoken in support of the Government's policy on the teaching of Chinese language. The response from the MPs is very encouraging. Teaching and learning of Chinese is a very important issue in

Column: 1894

Singapore. Before deciding on the changes, we have requested for and received feedback from the various quarters. I have personally spoken to the editors and journalists of the Chinese newspapers, the Chinese-educated MPs and listened to their views. Admiral Teo has also spoken and discussed with the Chinese Teachers' Union and their leaders on this issue. They all know where the crux of the matter is, where the question lies, where the problem is. Therefore, they also agree that it is necessary to revise the contents of the Chinese curricula and our policy on Chinese language. Of course, the Chinese community is very concerned about the adjustments to the level of Chinese language in our schools, and the proposed introduction of the CL `B' paper, and the impact, possibly negative impact, thereof. This concern is valid and quite understandable.

    We are making this adjustment to the level of Chinese language with two objectives. First, to nurture a group of Chinese elite, and secondly, to provide all students, especially those from the English-speaking families, a realistic level of Chinese for them to study and pass the examination set at this level.

    The bilingual education policy and the policy to learn mother tongue in schools will remain unchanged. The main policy will remain unchanged, but the details can be adjusted. In implementing this policy, we must do so in keeping with the changes of times and circumstances. We are a multi-lingual, multi-racial and multi-religious society. A Chinese cultural elite in this kind of a society has got a very important role to play. The spirit, the outlook in life and the social and political values of the Chinese-educated and Chinese elite are different from those of the English-educated. But, nevertheless, they complement one another. For example, the Chinese High School and RI are both excellent schools. Yet, the students they produce possess different characteristics and dispositions. We will be so much poorer if we have one without the other, and it will be a great loss.

    Therefore, in this regard, I agree with Dr Ker Sin Tze. We are not Japan. We cannot

Column: 1895

use Japanese as our national language. We are not Germany, we are not France. We are a multi-racial Singapore situated in Southeast Asia. Our working language is English and our international environment is also quite westernised. Therefore, it is not an easy thing to nurture a group of Chinese cultural elite here, but we are making efforts to make some changes to our education policy, and these are some of the examples. I think to increase the number of SAP schools and through other changes and all that I have announced, we can have positive results. I am confident of that.

    But we cannot go back to the old ways of the 1950s and 1960s. The Chinese schools then and the Chinese elites were products of certain historical circumstances. At that time we were a colony. The Chinese students were anti-colonialism and a mainstay in the fight for independence. Contributions from the English-educated in those days were relatively little. Amongst the Chinese-educated students, some were communists, some were not. After the merger with Malaysia, in the drive against communalism, the Chinese community also played a very important role. Because had the Chinese community bowed to the political pressure then, Singapore would be finished. But, now, that sort of situation has already passed us, it must therefore be put behind us.

    We all know that even in China or Hong Kong or Taiwan, values and traditions do not remain unchanged. So under certain political, social and cultural conditions, there are three different developments. The Chinese in Taiwan become "Taiwanised", even the Mandarin they speak is contaminated with the local Taiwanese dialects. In Hong Kong, you have a very strong local indigenous culture - the Cantonese culture with a very strong commercial flavour. This was because Hong Kong was a colony, an economy but not a sovereign nation. Now that it has become a Special Autonomy Region of China, it is also in the process of transformation. China has been opening up after the cultural revolution. With the economic

Column: 1896

reform and open-door policy, their culture and values are also evolving and changing. Therefore, the Chinese elite cannot remain unchanged. Our Chinese elite should move with the development of the Chinese culture and play an active role to promote and shape Singapore into a metropolitan city and economy in the 21st century.

    Our mother tongue policy must be realistic with the standard level of teaching and learning set at a level relevant to our students. Because of the limitations to our human brains, not many people have the capability to master two languages effectively, just as our computer does not necessarily have the capability to run every type of software, and if you overload it, things do not work out so well. So this is a question of brain, not a question of mouth and jaw.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang asked what is the bottomline for our Chinese education. He seems to imply that the Government has been too accommodating and has fixed too low a bottomline. My answer is that our bottomline is one that is achieveable by our average students with reasonable efforts in learning. This is our bottomline. We all have children. Most of us have children. We all know there are children who may be strong in certain subjects, and not so strong in some other subjects. I believe that the children of Mr Low Thia Khiang are also studying in our schools. But what are their results? What kind of problems do they face? Can you keep on applying pressure on them, just like the way you pump up the balloons? Your blood pressure will rise too.

    Many of our Members of Parliament learn through their own personal experiences that it is not easy for our children to master both English and Chinese at the same time. Even those who were educated in Chinese and who speak Mandarin at home also discover that the standard of Chinese of their children is lower than the good old days. Mr Peh Chin Hua has expressed regrets that although his children have been doing well in their Chinese examinations, their standard was still not to his satisfaction. Just imagine, what will be the level of Chinese in

Column: 1897

Singapore at the time of our grandchildren. What kind of problems will they face? Although we have not come to that stage, the time will come. So we have to face this reality.

    For the primary schools, I do not think there is much problem. But when you come to the secondary schools, it is more difficult. Let me tell you my personal experience. I spent 13 years learning Chinese, six years in a primary school, six years in a secondary school, and one year in the Junior College. They were all Chinese schools: Nanyang Primary School, Catholic High School and National Junior College. At home, I spoke Mandarin to my father. I learned Chinese, and he was also learning Chinese. But when I reached the secondary school level, I began to find it difficult. For the primary school level, I had no problem passing my Chinese examinations. At the Secondary Four `O' level examination, I worked very hard, but I managed only a C4. I was dissatisfied with myself. I worked harder. When I was in junior college, I had tuition and worked even harder. For the General Paper, known as Comprehension and Essay Writing, I had only a 6. Comprehension, no problem! Essay writing, there were problems. In a Chinese school, a "6", almost failed! If I had failed, there would be no scholarship for me. Fortunately, I passed.

    After that, one year, I went to NJC. I was not satisfied with my "6". I wanted to improve my Chinese. So I decided to take Chinese as a principal subject, or "A" level. For principal level Chinese, we had to learn classical Chinese (wen yen wen) and Chinese literature. After a few months, my teacher told me, "Your Chinese is not so good. Your lines of thoughts expressed in your essays are very messy." But I never had that kind of problem with my English essay writing. Why should I have this problem when I wrote in Chinese? It was not a question of content, but a question of language. However, the content and the language are closely linked because your brain has only a limited capacity. You are unable to express the idea clearly because you are too handicapped in your command of the

Column: 1898

language. So after a few months, I gave up. I did not take the principal Chinese paper in my `A' level examination.

    So I am convinced that learning Chinese is not an easy task. Even now, I read Lianhe Zaobao every day, and listen to news over Channel 8 every night. Yet, every time when I want to make a major speech in Mandarin or to be interviewed, I would still have to spend some time to prepare and practise in Mandarin. Otherwise, my expression, my sentences will not run smoothly and fluently. Expressions in English, and even English grammar will seep in, even the words I utter may not be in English. So I think it is not an easy problem to solve. Some students are learning their languages better than I do. I always admire those students who score distinctions in both languages, because I failed to do it. But I also know that there are many other students who are just like me, finding it difficult to learn Chinese.

    Our teachers have already known this as a fact. When I studied this problem, I asked some teachers, some Ministry of Education officials to introduce articles from the ancient Chinese classics in the curriculum of Higher Chinese. I told them that some of these Chinese classics were very meaningful and could have great impact on the students. If we can expose our students to these articles, this essence of Chinese literature will be of great benefit to them. But the teachers told me that this was not realistic, not quite possible. The simple reason is that the students may be taking Higher Chinese but if you want them to study classical Chinese, they just cannot cope with it. In formulating the curricula for our Higher Chinese, we face this restriction and constraint.

    Therefore, we must fix the level of Chinese at an appropriate and suitable level. This level cannot be decided by our likes or dislikes. It must go according to our experience and the level that is attainable by the students. If we can incorporate advanced technology into our teaching methods, then the level can be enhanced. If you tell me that you want to raise the standard of teaching, improve

Column: 1899

the quality of teachers without adjusting the difficult level of the Chinese paper, I think it cannot be accepted. We have tried to improve the teaching method. Yes, we must do that, but it is not the panacea to all our problems.

    Many Chinese-educated Members of Parliament also show their concerns about the curricula of the Chinese Language for EL `B' in that it should not be regarded as a "soft option". I agree with their views and we will pay specific attention to this aspect. But with our past experience in handling the level of Chinese teaching and learning in Singapore, we are confident that the situation will improve, because the parents are supportive of the idea of their children learning Chinese, albeit some may wish that the burden would not be too heavy. But, as the Minister has mentioned, according to our guidelines, at the Primary 4 streaming, about 13% to 14% of the cohort of students should qualify to take Higher Chinese. But because of the insistence of the parents, there are about 22% of ethnic Chinese students actually taking Higher Chinese, and most of them can cope with it.

    Parents encourage the students to take EM1 because they believe that it is better for their children to learn more. Moreover, most parents feel that their children are intelligent and should be encouraged to do EM1. I think this is some good social pressure which is acceptable.

    In our recent survey, 88% of parents feel that Chinese is an important subject. Students may or may not like Chinese but 80% to 90% recognise that it is an important subject. They may not know that they have to use Chinese to make big money in China. But they share the views of their parents, teachers, and the whole society. So we must take Chinese. If we do not do Chinese or do not do Chinese well, although you may not be denied a place, you will feel a little uncomfortable or rather ashamed.

    Why do more than 90% of the parents endorse the values from the Chinese

Column: 1900

culture? All these facts prove that the parents know that a knowledge of Chinese is an important and helpful thing to their children. They also know they want their children to learn Chinese. They are using all kinds of methods to supervise and encourage their children to master the Chinese language. They may engage a tuition teacher, even two or three tuition teachers, to coach their children. Some even send their children to Taiwan or China for "immersion courses". They offer all kinds of incentives and rewards - score 90 marks in your Chinese dictation, and I will buy you a Chinese software. They use all kinds of incentives, ways and means to encourage their children to learn Chinese. But if the pressure is too great, I think the children's attitude may change or their parents' attitude may change. Although they say they support, the feasibility must be studied. We cannot overlook or neglect the feedback from such parents.

    Today, the changes that we are making to the Chinese curriculum will help maintain our mother tongue education policy in the ever-changing circumstances. We must frequently discuss and review our mother tongue policy. This debate will not be the last one in this House. But so long as we continue to adjust our policy according to objective circumstances and make realistic approaches, we will be able to maintain the Chinese culture, Chinese traditions and Chinese values in us.

paper, such as EL `B', at a lower level so that they could pass English at a basic level and proceed to a junior college?

should be determined by the ability of our students. Whether our standard of English language should be lowered or not, it is for the parents to decide.     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Meat and fish are highly perishable products. Unsatisfactory handling or processing can cause rapid spoilage and serious food poisoning. Currently, there are two Acts which regulate the meat and fish industries to ensure that their products are safe for human consumption. These Acts, which were enacted in the 1960s, are:

    (a) The Slaughter-houses and Meat Processing Factories Act; and

    (b) The Fisheries Act. The provisions of these Acts are no longer adequate and need to be updated.

    Rather than amend the relevant sections of the two Acts, it is now more logical to promulgate a new Act to regulate solely the processing and sales of meat and fish meant for human consumption.

Column: 1936



    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, a comprehensive new Wholesome Meat and Fish Bill has therefore been drawn up. The main features of the Bill comprise four areas:

    (1) Regulating the import, export and transhipment of meat and fish products;

    (2) Licensing of slaughter-houses, processing establishments and cold stores;

    (3) Regulating the sale of meat and fish products; and

    (4) Improving PPD's operational effectiveness.

    I shall now go through and explain the rationale of the main features of the Bill.

Regulating the trade in meat and fish products

    Currently, the Fisheries Act adopts a two-tiered control system of licences and permits for traders wishing to import, export or tranship fish products. However, meat traders are not licensed. Provisions have therefore been included in the Bill to harmonise the requirements for the fish and meat trade.

    Under clauses 5 and 6 respectively, trading licences and permits for individual consignments will now be required. All meat and fish traders will have to be licensed. The requirement for permits for individual consignments will give PPD the flexibility to impose and enforce sanitary conditions on each consignment so as to prevent the introduction of animal diseases of public health significance such as anthrax or mad-cow disease into Singapore.

    Provisions have also been included to enhance the transparency of licensing procedures. This also allows Singapore to fulfil its WTO obligations. Clause 8 enables the Director of Primary Production to deny anyone an import licence, or to impose restrictions on the trade if he considers it necessary to safeguard public health. It, however, also requires the Director to provide the

Column: 1937

applicant with written reasons if he refuses to issue or renew the licence or permit applied for under the Act. Clause 9 allows any person aggrieved by the decision of the Director regarding the grant, renewal, suspension or revocation of a licence or permit, to appeal to the Minister.

Licensing of slaughter-houses, processing establishments and cold stores

    Clauses 11 and 12 require the slaughter-houses, meat and fish processing establishments and cold stores to be licensed. These provisions are largely based on the Slaughter-houses and Meat Processing Factories Act and the regulations on fish processing establishments under the Fisheries Act. These establishments will be required to meet standards set by the Director to ensure that slaughter, processing and storage conditions maintain the wholesomeness of the meat or fish products. The Director may also close any of these establishments if their condition poses a danger to health.

Sale of meat and fish products

    Clause 22 strengthens the regulation of the handling of meat and fish in wholesale markets. The wholesale trade of animals meant for food is also regulated to prevent the spread of diseases among the animals, and to control the handling of the animals which can have an impact on the safety and quality of the meat subsequently derived from these animals.

Improving PPD's operational effectiveness

    To allow PPD to overcome resource constraints and focus its limited manpower on the critical areas, clause 3 provides PPD the flexibility to outsource less critical operations to the private sector, such as the inspection of animals before and after slaughter at licensed slaughter-houses. However, to ensure that a high standard of food safety is maintained, PPD will specify the qualifications, training and experience required for authorised examiners.

Column: 1938



Enhancement of investigation and enforcement powers

    Clauses 24 to 27 strengthen the powers of investigation and enforcement. Clause 25 allows the Director to detain the confiscated items in the premises in which they were found. It also requires the owner or occupier of the premises to provide reasonable assistance to the Director or veterinary public health officer in the investigation. These powers are required as the meat or fish products under investigation may be in large quantities and due to their perishable nature, can only be practically detained in the place where they were found such as refrigerated containers or cold stores.

    Under the existing legislation, only the court can order forfeiture of items seized under the Acts. As this often results in prolonged detention of the items and incurring expensive storage charges, clause 32(9) has therefore been included to allow the owner of the seized items to consent to their disposal. Such items are deemed to be forfeited and may be disposed of as the Director thinks fit. This provision, however, does not prevent legal proceedings from being instituted against the owner of the items.

Enhancement of financial and custodial penalties

    Penalties of $500 to $2,000 fine and one-year imprisonment provided in the Slaughter-houses and Meat Processing Factories Act are grossly inadequate in today's context. Penalties should be commensurate with the value of the goods involved and the seriousness and impact of the offence. The penalties under this Bill therefore range from $1,000 to $100,000 for fines and 1 to 3 years for jail terms. These high penalties have been set to reflect the amount and value of the imported products, which may be in the order of hundreds of thousands of dollars. If such quantity of goods were contaminated and distributed to consumers, the impact on public health would be far-reaching. These high penalties are therefore necessary.

    There is also provision for offences to be compounded. The maximum sum for

Column: 1939

the composition of offences is $1,000. This would allow relatively minor offences under the Bill to be dealt with expeditiously without the need for instituting criminal proceedings against the offender.

"Presumption" clauses

    Under the existing legislation, a person found with illegally imported or processed meat or fish products can get off free from prosecution if he denies carrying out the import or processing. On average, PPD encounters about 2 to 3 such cases per year. This is not satisfactory as the consequences of distribution and consumption of large quantities of unwholesome meat or fish can be devastating to the public. To protect the consumers, clauses 6(5), 17(3), 20(3) and 23(3) have therefore been included to allow the person charged to show that he had taken reasonable precautions to prevent the commission of the offence, and that the offending act was done by someone else beyond his control.

Conclusion

    With the enactment of the new Act, the Slaughter-houses and Meat Processing Factories Act and relevant parts of the Fisheries Act will concurrently be repealed.

    In summary, the Wholesome Meat and Fish Bill will consolidate, update and strengthen existing regulations on the import, export and transhipment of meat and fish products; slaughter of animals; processing of meat and fish products and wholesale of fish. In addition, it will introduce regulation of wholesale of meat and animals intended for food. Powers of investigation and enforcement have also been strengthened to ensure that the provisions of the Bill are complied with, while the high penalties would act as a deterrent to anyone contemplating committing an offence under the Bill. This will ensure that meat and fish products continue to be safe for all Singaporeans to eat.

Objective

    The Construction Industry Development Board and the Building Control Division of the Public Works Department will be merged to form a new statutory board on 1st April 1999. The proposed Building and Construction Authority Bill 1999 will provide the required legislative framework for the formation of the new statutory board.

    The new statutory board will be called the Building and Construction Authority, BCA. Its mission will be to facilitate the development of a professional and technologically advanced construction industry that is capable of delivering world-class buildings and infrastructure at competitive prices.

Rationale

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, let me now share with this House the rationale behind the Government's decision to merge the Construction Industry Development Board (CIDB) and the Building Control Division (BCD) to form a new statutory board.

    CIDB was formed in 1984 to promote the development of technology and manpower in the construction industry. It has achieved much over the last fifteen years in terms of skill upgrading, quality, productivity and advanced technologies. Skill levels have increased from about 2% in 1984 to 27% in 1998. A comprehensive quality assessment system CONQUAS has been introduced and quality scores have increased steadily since its introduction in 1988. More than 4,000 contractors and suppliers are now registered with CIDB with more than 70 local contractors in the top-most category.

Column: 1942



    However, in recent years, before the economic downturn, the industry had expanded too rapidly. Productivity has slackened significantly as the industry resorted to short-term unproductive measures. The prevailing economic situation, therefore, allows us a very good opportunity to restructure the industry.

    Arising from a fundamental review of the various Government agencies dealing with the construction industry, we came to two conclusions. One, as previously announced, the non-regulatory functions of the Public Works Department should be corporatised. Two, there would be synergy arising from the merging of BCD of the PWD with the present CIDB. Unlike other industries, the construction industry operates within a well-defined regulatory framework - this is necessary because of the strong public interests at stake. While CIDB's development efforts have borne fruit in several areas, its progress has been moderated by the fact that it is not directly involved in the regulatory framework. Putting both the regulatory and the development efforts under one body will allow the new statutory board to co-ordinate the efforts of these two arms better. The new board will be able to leverage on the expertise and experience of both BCD and CIDB, and take an integrated approach towards restructuring the industry.

    We have taken the opportunity to make an amendment to allow the new BCA to make new regulations pertaining to the improvement of efficiency and standardisation of design, processes, construction techniques, products and materials. This will pave the way for the BCA to require mandatory minimum buildable scores for new buildings in a few years' time. The objective is to hasten the adoption of more buildable designs which allow the buildings to be built using more productive construction methods. Although CIDB has promoted buildable designs for several years, the adoption of such designs has been slow. Changes to Town Councils' Funds

    Let me talk about the proposed changes to section 33. The Bill seeks to make three changes to Town Councils' funds under section 33.

    At present, Town Councils are allowed to use their funds for the maintenance of facilities erected on common property in their towns. However, some improvement works put up by the Citizens' Consultative Committees (CCCs) under the Community Improvement Projects Committee (CIPC) scheme, or by Town Councils themselves during their Interim Upgrading Programmes (IUPs), were erected on non-common property in their towns. These facilities are mainly for the use and enjoyment of HDB residents living in the vicinity. Although funding was available for the construction of these facilities, there is no provision for their maintenance. Allowing the Town Councils to use their funds to maintain these facilities should therefore be viewed as an extension of the Town Councils' services to better address the needs of residents. In practical terms, Town Councils would also be in the best position to maintain such facilities which are not on common property. The Bill therefore seeks to allow Town Councils, with the approval of the Minister for National Development, to use the Town Councils' funds for the maintenance of facilities erected on non-common property in their towns.

    Next, the Town Councils Act currently does not allow Town Councils to make inter-activity transfer of funds in their sinking funds. Funds set aside for activities under "Market and Food Centres" cannot be used for activities under "Other Commercial Property". In reality, however, the market and food centres are an integral part of the shopping/commercial activities of the Neighbourhood Centres/Town Centres, as both activities, the market and food stalls and the commercial activities, complement each other. To streamline the financial operations of Town Councils, the Bill proposes to merge "Market and Food Centres" with "Other Commercial Property" under a single combined category called "Commercial Property". With this, their respective operating funds will be merged, as will

Column: 1961

their respective sinking funds. This will allow Town Councils to use the funds for the management, maintenance and improvement of the common areas for all types of commercial property within the Town.

    In addition, the Bill proposes to give the Minister for National Development the flexibility to prescribe the accounting method for the minimum amount of service and conservancy charges (S&CC) to be credited to the sinking funds established for residential and commercial properties. Prescribing the use of the accrual accounting method, which is based on the amount of S&CC collectible, will require Town Councils to reflect the S&CC arrears of their sinking funds in their financial statements. This will highlight the level of funds available for cyclical repairs and maintenance when the time comes.

Discretion to Levy Different Rates of Charges

    I move on now to section 38. Currently, section 38 of the Act only allows Town Councils to levy different rates of charges, ie, S&CC charges, for different types and uses of flats and stalls by way of by-laws. The Bill seeks to provide Town Councils the flexibility to levy different rates of charges for the same type of flats and stalls in accordance with such criteria as they may determine. For example, Town Councils could levy higher charges for upgraded flats and stalls as it costs more to maintain the upgraded facilities and the environment surrounding it. While this Bill allows Town Councils, if passed by Parliament, to charge different rates for the same flat type, I understand from the news report that the PAP Town Councils are unlikely to change the present S&CC charges. Similarly, differential charges could be levied according to the level of service and types of facilities required by residents. For example, some blocks of flats may require more cleaning compared to a different block of flats of the same type. So Town Councils will have the flexibility to charge different S&CC charges on the same flat type because it costs more to maintain a particular block

    I now move to section 21 of the proposed amendment. At present, HDB has a Board-wide Fire Insurance Policy to safeguard its properties, including the common property.
